research_topic_title: Diagnostic Cascade Losses at the Endoscopy Stage
executive_summary: The endoscopy stage is the single largest quantifiable bottleneck in the CD diagnostic cascade. Duodenal biopsy rates during EGD for CD-relevant indications range from 11–57% (community to academic center), and when biopsies are taken, only 35–40% meet the ≥4 specimen guideline threshold. Compound cascade probability — accounting for non-referral, non-biopsy, inadequate sampling, and pathology error — is estimated at ~15% for seropositive and <7% for seronegative Marsh 3a patients in routine community practice. For the reference patient (DQ8, Marsh 3A, all serology <1, low IgG1, low secretory IgA), estimated detection probability under current practice is <5%.

key_findings.finding: Duodenal biopsy is performed in only a minority of EGDs for CD-relevant indications (anemia, weight loss, diarrhea, iron deficiency). CORI database: 11% (2000–2003), rising to 43% (2004–2009). Columbia academic center: 57%. Provider-level range at single institution: 27–91%.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: 11–57% biopsy rate depending on era and setting
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All symptomatic patients at risk of undiagnosed CD, especially seronegative cases with Marsh 3A

key_findings.finding: Incomplete biopsy confirmation after positive IgA-tTG2 serology. Only 39% (Cleveland Clinic) to 72% (UK primary care) of seropositive adults complete duodenal biopsy. Meta-analytic data: approximately one-third of seropositive patients are never referred from primary care.
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Seropositive patients denied histologic confirmation or risk stratification

key_findings.finding: Guideline-recommended sampling (≥4 specimens) achieved in only 35–40% of duodenal biopsies. CD detection rate doubles with adherence (1.8% vs 0.7% US; 10.1% vs 4.6% UK).
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All patients reaching biopsy stage; Marsh 3a most vulnerable to undersampling

key_findings.finding: Normal-appearing mucosa in ~61% of diagnosed CD; endoscopic marker sensitivity only 59% (not stratified by Marsh grade; likely 20–40% for Marsh 3a). EMA sensitivity only 33% in partial villous atrophy vs 77% in total VA.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: 59% overall visual sensitivity; 33% EMA sensitivity in partial VA
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Marsh 3a patients, especially seronegative — simultaneously visually and serologically cryptic

key_findings.finding: IgG1 deficiency impairs mucosal IgA production via sequential IgM→IgG1→IgA class switching (Siniscalco 2025), providing a mechanistic explanation for false-negative IgA-tTG2 independent of HLA and distinct from selective IgA deficiency. Not detected by total IgA measurement.
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Patients with IgG1 subclass deficiency; directly applicable to the reference patient profile

key_findings.finding: Compound cascade probability at the endoscopy stage: ~15% for seropositive patients (all Marsh grades); ~7% for seronegative Marsh 3a in community practice; <5% for the reference patient profile.
key_findings.confidence_interval: Range 5–35% depending on practice setting (expert center vs community)
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All CD patients traversing the endoscopy stage

key_findings.finding: No-biopsy pathway (tTG-IgA ≥10×ULN) has 98.7% PPV but only 51% sensitivity — roughly half of adult CD patients are eligible, not 30% as previously misstated. The pathway cannot detect seronegative CD by definition. Enache et al. 2025 follow-up showed worse outcomes in no-biopsy diagnosed children.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: 51% sensitivity (95% CI 42–60%); 98.7–100% PPV; 0% sensitivity for SNCD
key_findings.affected_patient_population: ~49% of CD patients with tTG-IgA <10×ULN who still need biopsy; all SNCD patients

key_findings.finding: Diagnostic yield justifies automatic biopsy for IDA (3.2–5.5%), chronic diarrhea (8.5%), and especially their combination (19%), all above the 1.8% cost-effectiveness threshold. Dyspepsia/GERD (1.25–2%) is borderline. Unselected EGD (0.5–2%) falls below threshold.
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All patients undergoing EGD for these indications

key_findings.finding: Significant racial, age, and provider-type disparities in biopsy performance. Black patients OR 0.55; age ≥70 OR 0.51; surgeon endoscopists 18.2% adherence vs nurse endoscopists 51.2%.
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Black patients, elderly patients, patients seen by non-gastroenterologist endoscopists

key_findings.finding: QI interventions dramatically improve outcomes: EHR checklists raised adherence from 13.3% to 69.5%; education raised ≥4-specimen rates from 21.9% to 60.8% with CD detection doubling. Finland national case-finding achieved world's highest diagnosed CD prevalence (0.55%).

The commonly cited 2% seronegative CD prevalence is almost certainly a profound underestimate. Hujoel showed only 3.6% of seronegative patients are biopsied vs 79.2% of seropositive. Adjusted IgA-tTG2 sensitivity drops from 92.6% to 57%, implying 43% of CD patients may test seronegative.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: Reported 2% SNCD; adjusted model implies 10–43% depending on severity distribution
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All seronegative CD patients; the 2% figure is from verification-biased cohorts

biases_documented.description: Most CD prevalence and phenotype studies only include biopsied patients. Only 3.6% of seronegative patients are ever biopsied (Hujoel), meaning the seronegative CD prevalence estimate of '2%' is derived from a 96.4% unsampled denominator — at minimum a 25-fold undersampling relative to seropositive patients.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: 25-fold differential biopsy rate; adjusted IgA-tTG2 sensitivity drops from 92.6% to 57%

biases_documented.description: Endoscopists who biopsy only abnormal-appearing mucosa will diagnose CD only in the ~39% with visible markers, underestimating CD prevalence. This reinforces the belief that routine biopsy has low yield, perpetuating non-biopsy. Self-sustaining bias that cannot be broken without protocol-mandated biopsy.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: 41% of CD cases (61% normal-appearing mucosa) systematically missed by appearance-dependent practice

biases_documented.description: Core data from Columbia (57% biopsy rate) and Sheffield represent academic CD centers; community practice rates are likely 20–35%. CORI data (11–43%) better represents routine care.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: Community biopsy rates likely 20–35% vs academic 50–60%

biases_documented.description: Core datasets are 10–20 years old (CORI 2000–2009; Columbia 2007–2011). Post-2020 practice may differ due to guideline awareness, no-biopsy adoption, and COVID-era changes. No comprehensive post-2020 update exists.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: Unknown direction of change; some QI data suggests improvement, no-biopsy adoption may paradoxically reduce referral for borderline cases

biases_documented.bias_type: survivorship bias in QI intervention data
biases_documented.description: QI studies (Barnsley, pediatric EHR) represent motivated centers that chose to implement changes. Hawthorne effects and regression to mean may inflate effect sizes. Real-world scalability uncertain.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: Intervention effectiveness likely lower in routine implementation than in reported QI studies

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: The 2% seronegative CD prevalence is approximately correct
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Derived from serology-first cohorts where 96.4% of seronegative patients are never biopsied (Hujoel). Adjusted sensitivity of 57% implies 43% of CD patients may test negative. The '2%' reflects the tiny biopsied fraction, not the true population.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: The 2% figure is consistent across multiple cohorts. Some serology-independent screening studies also report low SNCD rates, though these used older histological criteria.
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: If true SNCD is 10–20% rather than 2%, the number of patients who can ONLY be diagnosed via indication-based biopsy is 5–10× larger than assumed, making the 43–57% biopsy gap far more consequential.

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: Visual endoscopic inspection has approximately known sensitivity for CD detection
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Oxentenko's 59% was not stratified by Marsh grade. Marsh 3a-specific visual sensitivity is likely 20–40%. No study has reported Marsh-grade-stratified endoscopic marker sensitivity.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: The 59% figure is consistent across studies (50–78% range) for mixed Marsh-grade cohorts.
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: If Marsh 3a-specific visual sensitivity is 20–30% rather than 59%, the biopsy-omission rate for 3a cases is even higher than aggregate data suggest.

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: No-biopsy pathways will reduce the non-referral problem rather than exacerbate it
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Enache 2025 showed worse outcomes in no-biopsy patients. Non-gastroenterologists may misinterpret 'no-biopsy pathway' as 'no referral needed.' Johnston (PMID 34966534) warned against applying NBP to any tTG positivity rather than high-titre only.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: ProCeDE and Bi.A.CeD demonstrate high PPV when criteria strictly applied; may reduce endoscopy burden.
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: Risk that NBP adoption widens the gap for the ~49% of CD patients with tTG2 <10×ULN who still require histological confirmation.

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: Routine biopsy for all CD-relevant indications is clearly justified
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Cost-effectiveness threshold of 1.8% not met for dyspepsia/GERD (1.25–2%) or unselected EGD (0.5–2%). Universal mandates increase pathology workload substantially for low-yield indications.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: IDA (3.2–5.5%), chronic diarrhea (8.5%), and their combination (19%) clearly exceed threshold. These account for the majority of CD-relevant EGDs.
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: Overstating case for universal biopsy may reduce credibility with guideline committees; stratified recommendations are more defensible.

overlooked_populations.population: Seronegative CD patients with Marsh 3a undergoing EGD for relevant indications but not biopsied
overlooked_populations.estimated_size: Unknown; if SNCD is 10–20% of true CD and indication-based biopsy rate is ~30% (community), roughly 7–14% of total CD population in this blind spot
overlooked_populations.why_missed: Triple invisibility: no serological flag, normal endoscopic appearance, low clinical suspicion. Additional mechanism: IgG1 deficiency → impaired IgA via Siniscalco pathway
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: Automatic duodenal biopsy protocols for IDA, chronic diarrhea, weight loss regardless of serology or appearance

overlooked_populations.population: Patients with positive serology who never complete biopsy
overlooked_populations.why_missed: Non-referral from primary care, endoscopist omission, patient refusal (~49% in screening; lower in symptomatic), premature GFD, endoscopy wait times (48.5 vs 34.5 days)
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: Systematic referral pathways; expanded no-biopsy criteria for high-titre; counseling against pre-biopsy GFD; reduced wait times

overlooked_populations.estimated_size: 5–10% of CD; no endoscopy-stage study stratifies by HLA genotype
overlooked_populations.why_missed: HLA genotyping not routine at endoscopy stage; DQ8 may associate with different Marsh distributions and serology levels
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: HLA-stratified subgroup analysis in biopsy completion and adequacy studies

overlooked_populations.population: Patients with IgG subclass deficiency causing false-negative serology via Siniscalco pathway
overlooked_populations.estimated_size: Unknown; IgG1 deficiency prevalence 2–5% in general population, overlap with CD unknown
overlooked_populations.why_missed: Mechanism published 2025; not yet integrated into CD diagnostic algorithms
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: IgG subclass measurement when serology negative but clinical suspicion persists; lower biopsy threshold for these patients

diagnostic_step_sensitivity.step_name: Endoscopy stage overall (referral → biopsy decision → adequate specimens → correct pathology)
diagnostic_step_sensitivity.reported_sensitivity: Not reported as compound figure in any published study
diagnostic_step_sensitivity.adjusted_sensitivity: Compound estimate: ~15% seropositive all Marsh grades; ~14% seropositive Marsh 3a; ~7% seronegative Marsh 3a (community); <5% reference patient profile
diagnostic_step_sensitivity.false_negative_rate: NOTE: Two distinct failure modes must be separated. (1) NON-PERFORMANCE RATE (patient never biopsied): 28–61% seropositive; 43–89% indication-based; >96% seronegative. (2) TECHNICAL FALSE-NEGATIVE RATE (biopsy performed but diagnosis missed): estimated 15–25% from inadequate specimens (<4), poor orientation, and pathologist inter-observer variability (κ=0.35 Marsh-Oberhuber; κ=0.53 for Marsh 3a)
key_limitations: Non-biopsy during EGD for relevant indications (43–89%)
Pathologist inter-observer disagreement (κ=0.35–0.53 depending on classification)
Premature GFD initiation before biopsy (negative correlation wait time ↔ Marsh grade)
No HLA genotype stratification available for any sub-step
All core data 10–20 years old; post-2020 update needed

contradictory_studies.citation: Penny et al. 2021 (Gut); Shiha et al. 2024 (Gastroenterology)
contradictory_studies.finding: PPV 98.7–100% for tTG-IgA ≥10×ULN supporting no-biopsy pathway in adults
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Current adult guidelines requiring biopsy for most cases. However, sensitivity only 51% — pathway misses ~49% of CD patients who need biopsy

contradictory_studies.finding: 8–10 year follow-up showed worse mucosal healing and dietary compliance in no-biopsy diagnosed children vs biopsy-diagnosed
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Assumption that no-biopsy diagnosis produces equivalent long-term outcomes

contradictory_studies.finding: Routine biopsy NOT cost-effective at base-case CD prevalence of 1% in GERD; becomes cost-effective at ≥1.8% prevalence
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Universal mandatory biopsy recommendations for all indications (supports stratified approach)

research_gaps.gap: No study has computed compound probability of correct CD diagnosis across ALL endoscopy sub-steps for a single patient traversal
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Integrated health system study tracking patients from referral through pathology report, documenting failure at each sub-step

research_gaps.gap: No Marsh-grade-stratified endoscopic marker sensitivity data (Marsh 3a vs 3b/3c)
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Prospective study correlating white-light endoscopy findings with Marsh grade, stratifying visual detection sensitivity by histological severity

research_gaps.gap: No HLA-genotype-stratified biopsy completion or adequacy data
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Retrospective cohort linking HLA genotyping results to endoscopy/biopsy outcomes

research_gaps.gap: Impact of IgG subclass deficiency on serology-to-biopsy cascade (Siniscalco mechanism)
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Prospective cohort measuring IgG subclasses alongside IgA-tTG2 and DGP-IgG in patients biopsied for CD-relevant indications regardless of serology result

research_gaps.gap: Post-2020 endoscopy-stage completion rates reflecting no-biopsy pathway adoption and COVID-era changes
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Multicenter registry or national database study (2020–2025) comparing pre/post no-biopsy guideline adoption

research_gaps.gap: Prospective studies using serology- and appearance-independent systematic biopsy to establish unbiased SNCD prevalence
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Multicenter mandatory biopsy in all EGDs for IDA/diarrhea/weight loss with central pathology review

research_gaps.gap: True diagnostic sensitivity of duodenal biopsy specifically for Marsh 3a, accounting for specimen count, orientation, and pathologist variability
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Multi-pathologist re-read study of standardized Marsh 3a biopsies with varying specimen counts and orientation quality

research_gaps.gap: Feasibility and unintended consequences of 'duodenal biopsy rate' quality metric (pathology burden, cost per diagnosis by indication)
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Pilot implementation at multiple centers measuring biopsy rate, workload impact, CD yield by indication, and cost

differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: Villous atrophy, symptoms of malabsorption, iron deficiency
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: Medication history, resolution on drug cessation, negative celiac serology (though seronegative CD also has this)

differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: Villous atrophy, chronic diarrhea, malabsorption; may have low IgA and IgG subclasses similar to reference patient
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: Recurrent sinopulmonary infections, low total immunoglobulins, absent plasma cells on biopsy; CD and CVID can coexist

differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: False-negative IgA-tTG2 by definition (total IgA <7 mg/dL); 2–8% of CD patients
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: Total serum IgA <7 mg/dL; guidelines recommend IgG-based testing (DGP-IgG, tTG-IgG) but these have lower sensitivity
Anti-enterocyte antibodies, typically refractory to GFD, extra-intestinal autoimmune features

differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: Chronic diarrhea, weight loss, potential villous changes
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: Travel history, response to antibiotics, different histological pattern

recommendations.recommendation: Implement automatic duodenal biopsy protocols stratified by indication: MANDATORY for IDA, chronic diarrhea, and IDA+diarrhea (yield 3.2–19%, all above 1.8% cost-effectiveness threshold); RECOMMENDED for unexplained weight loss; DISCRETIONARY for dyspepsia/GERD (borderline cost-effective at 1.25–2%)
recommendations.target: guidelines (ACG, BSG, ESGE), endoscopy units, quality programs
recommendations.evidence_basis: Mahadev 2018 (PMID 29689265) meta-analysis; Yang & Lebwohl 2015 (PMID 25818076) cost-effectiveness threshold

recommendations.recommendation: Establish 'Duodenal Biopsy Rate for CD-Relevant Indications' quality metric analogous to colonoscopy's adenoma detection rate, tracking the decision to biopsy (not just specimen count)
recommendations.evidence_basis: 27–91% provider variation (PMID 29095420); no existing metric for biopsy decision

recommendations.recommendation: Frame all seronegative CD prevalence estimates as lower bounds due to verification bias. The 2% figure is derived from cohorts where 96.4% of seronegative patients are never biopsied.
recommendations.evidence_basis: Hujoel et al. (PMID 32433257): differential biopsy rate creates 25× undersampling of seronegative patients

recommendations.recommendation: Screen for IgG subclasses when IgA-tTG2 is negative but clinical suspicion persists, based on Siniscalco 2025 mechanism showing IgG1 deficiency impairs mucosal IgA production independently
recommendations.evidence_basis: Siniscalco et al. Immunity 2025; applies directly to reference patient profile

recommendations.recommendation: Qualify no-biopsy pathway endorsement with Enache 2025 follow-up data showing worse long-term outcomes, and emphasize that NBP cannot detect seronegative CD (~49% of CD patients have tTG-IgA <10×ULN per Shiha sensitivity data)
Require HLA-stratified subgroup reporting in future biopsy completion and adequacy studies to assess whether DQ8 patients have different outcomes
recommendations.evidence_basis: No existing HLA-stratified endoscopy-stage data despite known phenotypic differences

recommendations.recommendation: Strong counseling against gluten-free diet initiation before diagnostic completion; reduce EGD wait times to <30 days for CD-relevant indications (current median 48.5 days)
recommendations.evidence_basis: Negative correlation between wait time and Marsh grade at biopsy (PMID 33455912)

meta_analysis_summary.heterogeneity_notes: Significant variation by country (US vs UK vs Finland), era (2000–2009 vs 2010–2020), setting (academic CD center vs community), and indication. US CORI database studies dominate quantitative estimates; UK multicentre data provides QI intervention evidence. No comprehensive post-2020 data available. Expert center data (Columbia, Sheffield) likely overestimate community practice.
